title: 105_hr3568
content: The Act titled "Mental Health and Substance Abuse Parity Amendments of 1998" revises limits on mental health benefits. The Mental Health and Substance Abuse Parity Amendments of 1998 expand coverage under ERISA for group health plans and insurance to include treatment limitations and financial requirements for mental health benefits. The Mental Health and Substance Abuse Parity Amendments of 1998 ensure that group health plans cannot impose treatment limitations or financial requirements on mental health benefits that are not imposed on medical and surgical benefits in similar settings. This section does not prohibit plans from negotiating separate reimbursement rates or managing benefit provision for different services. The Mental Health and Substance Abuse Parity Amendments of 1998 prohibit group health plans from limiting coverage of medically necessary benefits through pre-admission screening and prior authorization. It also mandates specific mental health benefits and prevents plans from excluding preventive care under subsection (a). The Mental Health and Substance Abuse Parity Amendments of 1998 prohibit group health plans from limiting coverage of medically necessary benefits through pre-admission screening and prior authorization. It also mandates specific mental health benefits and prevents plans from excluding preventive care. Treatment limits refer to restrictions on the frequency, number of visits, or scope of treatment, while financial limits include copayments and deductibles. The Mental Health and Substance Abuse Parity Amendments of 1998 prohibit group health plans from imposing cost-sharing requirements like copayments, deductibles, and out-of-network charges. It also eliminates cost exemptions and sunset provisions, while expanding coverage to include treatment and financial limitations under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Mental Health and Substance Abuse Parity Amendments of 1998 prohibit group health plans from imposing cost-sharing requirements on mental health benefits. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to ensure that group health plans do not impose treatment limitations or financial requirements on mental health benefits if similar limitations are not imposed on medical and surgical benefits. The Mental Health and Substance Abuse Parity Amendments of 1998 prohibit group health plans from imposing cost-sharing requirements on mental health benefits, ensuring equal treatment with medical and surgical benefits. Group health plans are allowed to negotiate separate reimbursement rates and manage benefit provision through various mechanisms. The Mental Health and Substance Abuse Parity Amendments of 1998 prohibit group health plans from imposing cost-sharing requirements on mental health benefits. Treatment limits are defined as restrictions on the frequency, number of visits, or scope of treatment covered by a group health plan, excluding limits based solely on medical necessity. The Mental Health and Substance Abuse Parity Amendments of 1998 prohibit cost-sharing requirements on mental health benefits, including treatment limits not based solely on medical necessity. Financial requirements like copayments and deductibles are also restricted. Amendments eliminate cost exemptions and sunset provisions in the section. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to remove the word "certain" from a specific section. Additionally, the Public Health Service Act is amended to include a new section related to individual health insurance. SEC. 2752. PARITY IN THE APPLICATION OF LIMITS TO MENTAL HEALTH BENEFITS. The provisions of section 2705 apply to health insurance coverage in the individual market as they do to coverage in connection with a group health plan. Effective dates for group health plans begin on or after July 1, 1999. In the case of a group health plan under collective bargaining agreements ratified before this Act, amendments do not apply until the last agreement terminates. The amendment made by subsection (d) applies to individual health insurance coverage and any plan amendment made to conform to new requirements added by subsection (a), (b), or (c) shall not terminate a collective bargaining agreement. Effective July 1, 1999, the provisions of the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996 and the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 will apply to individual health insurance coverage in the market. Coordination in implementation is required for compliance with the new regulations. The Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996 and the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 will apply to individual health insurance coverage, requiring compliance with new regulations under title XXVII of the Public Health Service Act and the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. SEC. 3. PARITY IN THE APPLICATION OF LIMITS TO SUBSTANCE ABUSE AND CHEMICAL DEPENDENCY BENEFITS. This section amends the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 to ensure parity in the application of limits to substance abuse and chemical dependency benefits. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 ensures parity in the application of limits to substance abuse and chemical dependency benefits, as stated in section 713. This amendment applies to group health plans and health insurance issuers under the Public Health Service Act. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 ensures parity in the application of limits to substance abuse and chemical dependency benefits under section 713. This amendment also applies to group health plans under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 ensures parity in the application of limits to substance abuse and chemical dependency benefits under section 9812, similar to mental health benefits. "Sec. 9813 ensures parity in limits for substance abuse and chemical dependency benefits. Section 2753 under the Public Health Service Act extends this parity to mental health benefits." The provisions of section 2752 apply to substance abuse and chemical dependency treatment benefits in the same way as they do to mental health benefits. Effective dates for group health plans begin on or after July 1, 1999. The amendments do not apply to collective bargaining agreements ratified before the enactment of the Act, with plan years starting before July 1, 1999. The amendment made on July 1, 1999, under a collective bargaining agreement does not terminate the agreement. Individual health insurance coverage is affected by the amendment starting July 1, 1999.
